title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the actual rate of unemployment as 6% and/or does not show the work.

Unemployed Labor Force ×100= 100 million−94 million 100 million ×100=6% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7657@

The response calculates the actual rate of unemployment as 6% and shows the work.

Unemployed Labor Force ×100= 100 million−94 million 100 million ×100=6% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7657@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the economy is facing an inflationary gap and/or does not explain that short-run equilibrium real output ($850 billion) is greater than potential real output ($750 billion).
The response states that the economy is facing an inflationary gap and explains that short-run equilibrium real output ($850 billion) is greater than potential real output ($750 billion).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not explain that nominal wages, input prices, and inflationary expectations will increase, which will cause short-run aggregate supply to decrease until real output decreases to potential (full-employment) output.

The response explains that nominal wages, input prices, and inflationary expectations will increase, which will cause short-run aggregate supply to decrease until real output decreases to potential (full-employment) output.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does none of the following:
The response does one of the following:
The response does both of the following:

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the actual rate of unemployment in the short run is greater than the natural rate of unemployment and/or does not explain that the economy is now facing a recessionary gap because short-run equilibrium real output is less than potential real output.

The response states that the actual rate of unemployment in the short run is greater than the natural rate of unemployment and explains that the economy is now facing a recessionary gap because short-run equilibrium real output is less than potential real output.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that a decrease in national savings will increase the equilibrium real interest rate and/or does not explain that the supply of loanable funds will decrease (or the demand for loanable funds will increase because public savings decreased and the government needs to borrow more).

The response states that a decrease in national savings will increase the equilibrium real interest rate and explains that the supply of loanable funds will decrease (or the demand for loanable funds will increase because public savings decreased and the government needs to borrow more).
